42.text: (Michael Sweere) I tell people that I'm a visual artist

44.text: and that I specialize in creating artwork

47.text: from recycled and reclaimed salvage material.

51.text: When they ask me what does that mean,

53.text: I tell them I build mosaics, and I build collages.

57.text: When they say well, what's the style like?

59.text: I tell them it's somewhere in between fine art and folk art,

63.text: and they look at me puzzled,

65.text: but they say well, that sounds neat. [laughs]

80.text: I started out on my career path

82.text: going to school and getting a degree in commercial art,

85.text: which led to getting a job in advertising agencies

89.text: and I worked as a designer

91.text: and art director for almost 20 years.

95.text: It started out as a hobby with my son,

98.text: and when he was a little kid, we would spend Saturday afternoons

102.text: trying to think of projects to do together.

104.text: We were having our breakfast in the morning and I said,

107.text: we could take this cereal box

109.text: and we could make a mosaic out of it.

112.text: He said let's do it, and we used a Apple Jacks box.

114.text: We got it done, and he thought it was so neat,

117.text: he loved, as I cut up pieces, he'd sort out the colors

119.text: and we abstractly laid the pieces in, and he looked at it,

122.text: and he said it looks like a rabbit jumping out of a hole.

126.text: And in an abstract way I thought, it really does,

128.text: and that really was the moment when I realized

132.text: it's like well, if we could do an abstract rabbit

135.text: out of a cereal box in an hour, what if I spent a whole day

139.text: or a week working on a mosaic project made out of cereal boxes?

143.text: And it clicked, and that's where it all started.

146.text: I worked on a lot of packaged goods accounts,

149.text: cereal and snack foods and soda,

152.text: and consequently I always had an office full of packaging

155.text: and I realized that it would be a really fun medium

159.text: to learn how to do mosaics with.

161.text: I was a little intimidated with just diving in and trying to work with tile or glass,

165.text: but paper packaging I had lots of

168.text: and I just started cutting up old boxes

171.text: and that's kinda how I taught myself the basic techniques

175.text: in doing mosaic and collage work.

186.text: In 2005 I was able to leave my advertising job

190.text: and pursue working on my mosaic and fine art work full time.

198.text: When I'm sourcing my materials, most of the recycled, reclaimed,

203.text: used stuff that I look for comes from thrift stores.

206.text: One blue tile for 25 cents, I'll take that.

210.text: This is the Habitat for Humanity ReStore in New Brighton.

216.text: For tile, this is the best place to find it.

218.text: It's kinda been my hidden secret.

221.text: These were probably really expensive at one time.

224.text: I don't have a project I can use them on right now, I wish I did.

229.text: Somebody else is gonna find these and really luck out.

233.text: A whole box of them for $25, that's a pretty good deal.

237.text: My favorite kinda tile to work with

246.text: Now that I've been doing mosaic and collage work

249.text: for the last 10, 15 years, I've got a pretty good collection

253.text: of my own material, and in my basement,

255.text: I almost have my own thrift store setup.

268.text: Sometimes I can do an entire project

270.text: just from all the material that I have here.

272.text: I have friends and relatives who go out and do picking for me.

276.text: Occasionally people will give me old antique plates

278.text: that they've had or been in their family collection

281.text: and have gotten chipped or broken.

283.text: Typically, instead of throwing them out,

285.text: they usually ask me if I can use them

287.text: and incorporate them into projects, and I just love it.

290.text: And often clients will give me old dishware of theirs

293.text: because it reminds them of a relative or family member

296.text: and I'll try to incorporate that into the actual design too.

318.text: Right now I'm working on a tile mosaic backsplash

324.text: in the mornings when I've got good light.

326.text: I had met with the client a couple months ago

329.text: and they told me they would really like to do

331.text: a Day of the Dead skeleton theme.

334.text: The first thing that I do is a pencil drawing.

337.text: Once this was approved by the client,

339.text: I took the pencil drawing of the artwork,

342.text: brought it to a copy center

344.text: and had an oversize black-and-white copy made,

348.text: took the copy, laid it down onto a piece of tile board,

352.text: and using carbon paper, I transferred that design

355.text: and upon transferring it, I use a magic marker

359.text: and go over that and get a nice solid outline for me to use,

363.text: so it's almost like a coloring book at this point, and now

366.text: I just figure out where all the tile colors are going to go.

373.text: It's really fun for me, when I find these interesting patterns,

381.text: but to kind of hide them, so that as the viewer

384.text: sees the piece from a distance, they're drawn into

388.text: trying to figure out what it's made of,

390.text: or maybe they just like the design,

393.text: but I think if there's a real payoff when they go

395.text: and they look at it up close, and they see,

399.text: well, this landscape that looks like

400.text: there's a rainstorm going on, the rain isn't rain,

403.text: it's bar codes off of paper packaging or tin packaging.

408.text: [12-string acoustic guitar; finger-picking in bright rhythm]

415.text: I'm working on a series of tin collages in the afternoons.

421.text: they're a whole series of wild animals.

424.text: And this is a great horned owl.

437.text: A lot of my tin work that I do comes from canisters

440.text: that people were gonna just throw in the recycling bin.

443.text: And it's rewarding for me to know that,

445.text: rather than have somebody throw something out

447.text: or just put it in recycling where it gets melted again,

450.text: that I can turn it into a piece of artwork.

453.text: And it's kinda cool because even the scraps that I don't use,

456.text: then I in turn can put those in the recycling bin and there's

460.text: not much of a footprint left from any of the work that I do.

463.text: I try to get the most usage out of everything.

474.text: You can see some of my mosaic work

478.text: The Mayo Clinic in Rochester has a couple of pieces of mine.

488.text: that I've created for them in the last few years.

491.text: Children's Hospital in St. Paul has some work.

494.text: When I do work for hospitals or schools or libraries,

501.text: there's a sense of reward with it.

502.text: Oftentimes the themes that I get to work on are pretty fun.

505.text: The artwork is meant to cheer people up

508.text: in a kind of a tough situation,

510.text: and so to create a piece of artwork

512.text: that's designed to try to boost people's feelings

515.text: and make 'em feel better, that's rewarding in itself

518.text: and occasionally I'll hear back, I'll get an email from somebody

521.text: saying, you know, my husband was in the hospital

524.text: or my grandmother was there and I was in a really bad mood

527.text: and I walked out and I saw one of your mosaics and it made me feel so good.

532.text: To get that kind of feedback is just the best feeling in the world,

535.text: you know, it just makes me feel like I've got a purpose

538.text: for the artwork that I'm creating--I just love that.

554.text: [acoustic guitar; slowly strumming, folk music chords]

867.text: (Angel) Well, I absolutely love coffee, and I drink a ton of it.

945.text: Painting with coffee is nice because it doesn't require

950.text: or anything like that, so it's very easy cleanup, easy setup,

954.text: so it's a fun medium because we can do it in a coffee shop,

967.text: Today's artwork, we plan to call it Coffee Run,

993.text: because it's just one color, the color brown.

998.text: So we have to focus more on the other elements

1001.text: such as contrast or layout or form and that sort of thing,

1005.text: because we can't use those pops of color to add interest.
